"Just taking it one day at a time and Lord willing I'll come out with the W" Ahhhh the age old rhetoric of the professional athlete. Anyone who know me knows I do a rather stunning impression of a hockey players mid-period interview, being sure to add in as many cliches as humanly possible before I scurry into the locker room to dump the same crap once again on my teammates as a rally cry for another goal. "Just gotta give it 110% out there" "We're not doing a good job taking away time and space" - ahh the good ole time and space (homage to Pierre McGuire) "We gotta respect his abilities out there" "I'm tryin to play hard in the corners" And of course the all time favs "Just have to take it one game at a time" and "Hopefully we'll come out with a "W" tonight" Now for years and years I thought this crap was just...well...crap. Until recently when I found myself in my London Life / Freedom 55 Training course. The nature of this course was that in the first 2 week we are preparing and studying to write our Mutual Funds exam. The balance of the course is dedicated to the LLQP (Life License Qualification Program) I not only was told to put the LLQP out of mind completely for now, but found myself completely focused and able to actually do so...making the statement "One day at a time" completely apply. I never thought when I heard an athlete say this that they were actually able to do this...to not think about the next game at all until the first game is finished. But now that I have written my IFIC (Mutual Funds Exam) I find myself not only relieved, but not thinking about it at all, I have moved on to thinking about my preparation for the LLQP. I find this new skill I have acquired actually quite invigorating and exciting, adding an aspect of complete and utter focus on one task....something most of you would know I typically am not able to do. So in an attempt at living vicariously the life of a professional athlete....here's to "Taking it one day at a time and hopefully coming out with the "W"

THINK YOU'RE HAVING A BAD DAY - Which I was until now. Fire authorities in California found a corpse in a burned out section of forest while assessing the damage done by a forest fire. The deceased male was dressed in a full wet suit, complete with scuba tanks on his back, flippers, and face mask in the middle of the forest. A post-mortem test revealed that the man died not from burns, but from massive internal injuries. Dental records provided a positive identification. Investigators then set about to determine how a fully clad diver ended up in the middle of a forest fire. It was revealed that on the day of the fire, the man went diving off the coast, some 20 miles from the forest. The fire fighters, seeking to control the fire as quickly as possible, had called in a fleet of helicopters with very large dip buckets. Water was dipped from the ocean and emptied at the site of the forest fire. You guessed it. One minute our diver was making like Flipper in the Pacific, the next, he was doing the breast stroke in a fire dip bucket 300 feet in the air and then airborne into smoke heaven.
